EXECUTIVE SUMMARY ELEMENTS


Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies

    Accidental Release Prevention:

All areas of release prevention for The City of Oldsmar Wastewater Facility are contained in the City's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). This is a comprehensive plan that encompasses all aspects of the City of Oldsmar's WWF methods and procedures of receiving, handling, processing and worst as well as alternative accidental release scenarios of hazardous chemicals on site. 


    Emergency response Policies:

The City of Oldsmar Wastewater Facility's response to emergencies is controlled by 4 main elements/policies: 

X Risk Management Plan
X Process Safety Management
X Chlorine Emergency Response Action Plan
X Sulfur Dioxide Emergency Response Action Plan



The management of the City of Oldsmar's Wastewater Facility has had a safety program in effect since 1991. Since inception, the program has undergone extensive change. The evolution process has taken this program from the early planning, research and development stages to a well defined, structured and to this date, safe & successful program. This is evidenced by a track record with respect to "employee time lost" and "vehicle time lost, accident" awards received from the National Safety Council. This years' requirement for the RMP, PSM, and other accompanying plans pro

vide an opportunity to update, revise and in some cases create the necessary plans needed to assure the ultimate in safety for both employees and surrounding residents. 


Regulated Substances Handled

X Chlorine (Cl2)up to 6000 lbs.
X Sulfur Dioxide (SO2).up to 6000 lbs.



The City of Oldsmar's Wastewater Facility is located at 351 Lafayette Boulevard has a primary function to receive, treat, and dispose of sanitary sewage. The treated effluent is discharged to Mobbley Bay or sold as reclaimed water to residents of the City. 

Chlorine is used in the wastewater treatment process to remove harmful bacteria in the water, as required by FDEP/EPA regulations, prior to discharge into Mobbley Bay or into the reclaimed distribution system.

Sulfur Dioxide is used in the wastewater treatment process for the dechlorination of Plant effluent, prior to discharge into Mobbley Bay. This effluent dechlorination process is required in order to avoid a negative impact to the flora and fauna in the surrounding surface waters.

Both of these processes occur in the same building, identified to as the "Chlorine Building". This building is located at the southernmost side of the Wastewater Facility.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Greater communication between safety officials and employees is and will continue to be the key to greater safety. Through monthly safety meetings, which focus on all aspects of safety, all employees are continually reminded of potential disaster and how to avoid it. 

As new "state of the art" products are developed, they will be considered, and if appropriate, purchased by the respective divisions. 

Any new programs such as the RMP will in fact be our biggest "Planned changes" to our Safety Program. Whereas our Safety Program is gradually evolving into an efficient and highly functional program, minor refining is all that is currently planned for the upcoming years. The current system proves to be functioning quite well and will continue to change with the times, as well as keep up with the ever-changing industry standards.

Dear Mr. Mannello,

O'Brien & Gere Engineers, Inc. (O'Brien & Gere) is pleased to submit this letter report summarizing results of the specific components of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) developed for the City of Oldsmar Wastewater Facility WWF) located in Oldsmar, Pinellas County, Florida.  This letter report has been prepared in accordance with our proposal of March 29, 1999 and our on-site investigation of April 29, 1999.

The tasks performed for this study included: 

7 Task 1 - Developing Draft What-If scenarios for both Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide processes
7 Task 2 - Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide - Wor

st-case release scenario modeling using RMP* Comp model
7 Task 3 -  Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide - Alternate-case release scenario modeling using RMP* Comp model
7 Task 4 - Identifying the public and environmental receptors impacted by the worst-case and alternate-case releases of Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide


Task 1 - Developing What-If scenarios for both Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide processes

Draft What-If scenarios for the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide processes were developed for the facility to meet the requirements of the RMP (See Attachment 1 & 2).  It is our understanding that City of Oldsmar WWF will be conducting a Process Hazard Analysis Team meeting and will update the What-If Scenarios for both systems.  The final What-If Scenarios will be inserted into the individual RMP sections. 
 Task 2 - Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide - Worst-case release scenario modeling

In accordance with 40 CFR 68 Subpart B - Hazard Assessment, facilities which are defined as Program 3 are required to evaluate one worst-case release scenario analysis in the RMP for each regulated substance at the facility.  The RMP rule defines the worst-case release as "the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or a process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint". The worst-case release quantity is the greatest amount held in a single vessel, taking into account any administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity.   

EPA established "endpoints" for release modeling analysis, which would result in no adverse impact to public health.  For toxins, the endpoint is the chemical concentration in the air to which a person can be exposed to up to an hour without serious health effects.  EPA's endpoint concentration for Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide is 3 ppm.  Air dispersion modeling using Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) approved RMP* Comp was performed to calculate the impacts of; one (1) ton (2,000 lbs) cylinder of chlorine and anoth

er calculation for; one (1) ton (2,000 lbs) cylinder of Sulfur Dioxide released to the atmosphere.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for the Chlorine worst-case scenario is 0.96 miles.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for the Sulfur Dioxide worst-case scenario is 0.94 miles.

In accordance with 40 Code of Federal Regulation (CFR) 68.30, the off-site impacts resulting from a worst-case release scenario are evaluated by estimating the population within a circle with its center at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the endpoint.  Therefore, under the worst-case release scenario, a circular area with a calculated radius of 0.96 miles (mi.) from the Chlorine system and 0.94 mi. from the Sulfur Dioxide system around the facility could be potentially affected  (See Figure 1).

The WWF lies within City of Oldsmar in Pinellas county, Florida.  According to the latest information attainable from the U.S. Census Bureau, City of Oldsmar has a population density of 933.8 population/square mile (U.S. Census Bureau 1990).  Based on this information, it is estimated that up to 2702 people are within the circular area under the worst-case release scenario from the Chlorine system and 2590 people from the worst-case release scenario from the Sulfur Dioxide system.


Task 3 -  Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide - Alternate-case release scenario modeling

In accordance with 40 CFR 68.28, the facility is required to identify and analyze at least one alternative-case release scenario (ACS) for inclusion in the RMP for each regulated substance.  The alternative release scenario can be venting of one of the covered process systems due to a component failure (i.e., container, piping) that results in concentrations above the toxic endpoint beyond the property line.  The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) (40 CFR 68.67), which is part of the prevention program, states that an alternative release scenario must reach an endpoint off-site, unless no such alternative release scen

ario exists. Criteria for selection of the ACS included: 

7    more likely release scenario that results in an off-site impact
7    may account for passive and active mitigation, and administrative controls
7    release at actual release height
7    may account for more representative meteorological conditions of D stability and 3.14 m/s wind speed
 
In evaluating the ACS, the OCA team considered several options, and selected several potential ACSs based on:

7    actual operating history and toxic substance release history
7    guidance provided by EPA in OCA guidance and in the Model Plan for Ammonia Refrigeration
7    scenarios identified in previous PHA studies (i.e., Occupational Safety and Health Administration     (OSHA)'s Process Safety Management (PSM) What-if Scenarios)

The alternate-case release scenario identified for both substances for RMP OCA requirements is a disconnection of the feed manifold at the tanks.  

Air dispersion modeling RMP* Comp was performed to calculate the impacts of  Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide from a 0.049 square inch area opening over a 10 minute period released to the atmosphere.  The distance to the toxic endpoint of 3 ppm for the Chlorine worst-case scenario is 0.10 mi.  The distance to the toxic endpoint of 3 ppm for the Sulfur Dioxide worst-case scenario is 0.10 mi..

In accordance with 40 Code of Federal Regulation (CFR) 68.30, the off-site impacts resulting from a worst-case release scenario are evaluated by estimating the population within a circle with its center at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the endpoint.  Therefore, under the worst-case release scenario, a circular area with a calculated radius of 0.10 mi. from the Chlorine system and 0.10 mi. from the Sulfur Dioxide system around the facility could be potentially affected  (See Figure 2).

The WWF facility lies within City of Oldsmar in Pinellas county, Florida.  According to the latest information attainable from the U.S. Census Bureau, City of Oldsmar has

a population density of 933.8  population/square mile (U.S. Census Bureau 1990).  Based on this information, it is estimated that up to 29 people are within the circular area under the alternative-case release scenario from the Chlorine system and from the Sulfur Dioxide system.


Task 4 - Identifying the public and environmental receptors

The regulation requires the identification of public receptors within the circle defined by the worst-case release scenarios.  Public receptors include "off-site residences, institutions (e.g. schools and hospitals), industrial, commercial, and office buildings, parks, or recreational areas inhabited or occupied by the public at any time without restriction by the stationary source where members of the public could be exposed to toxic concentrations, radiant heat, or overpressure, as a result of an accidental release."  Off-site means areas beyond the facility property boundaries and "areas within the property boundary to which the public has routine and unrestricted access during or outside business hours."  City of Oldsmar choose to list the following public receptors based on a number of different factors including the number of people at the industry and proximity to the city.


Public Receptors impacted from the worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios include

Environmental receptors are limited to natural areas such as national parks, monuments, wilderness areas, forests, state parks, officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges.  There are

no environmental receptors included within the worst-case and alternate-case release scenario areas.
